3b630800966be5c4f7eb283c363eb7f4 (00:13): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: doesn't seem like a big deal to have a few extra properties
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:15): just doesn't seem very clean
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:28): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: we're gonna solve the problem by not making UTF-32 an encoding label
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:29): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: i.e. "utf-32" is the same as "abacadabra"
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:30): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: that doesn't help unless WebKit and IE are willing to drop UTF-32 support (whether at the autodetect level or entirely)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:31): if they are, then it's easy
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:32): there's not much we can do about proprietary extensions
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:34): but if they won't remove that, then there's not much point to the spec shaking its fist more loudly at utf-32
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:34): either way the spec and implementations will differ
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:36): the spec just makes some recommendations because we're in a transition
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:36): and because encodings are poorly defined at best
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:36): I have some ideas on how to do better, but I haven't written down an actual spec yet

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:37): i mean, currently ie and webkit differ from the spec at step 4 (step 4--if you get there--says utf-32 must be detected as utf-16, those browsers don't do that); explicitly forbidding utf-32 as a supported encoding would just change where those browsers differ from the spec
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:37): (step 4 being the BOM header step)
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:38): nothing wrong with being more explicit, of course (it's a lateral move, not a step back)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:40): UTF-32 is pretty much forbidden
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:40): unless you have a very good reason to support
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:40): but in practice, that's not the case :(
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:41): I don't really expect implementations to catch up with all the details of the specification within a couple of years after it was introduced
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:41): that almost never happens
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:42): it took half a decade for the HTML5 parser to gain some support
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:42): sure, if you think that they'll eventually be willing to remove utf-32 outright, that's fine (even if it takes a few years)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:42): pretty close to a decade now for <input type=date> and that's still in its infancy
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:43): oh yeah, I expect them to remove support for it eventually
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:43): i don't know if the utf-32 support is purely "we implemented it with everything else and don't really need it" or actual legacy compat
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:43): which is the real question there, of course
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:44): just like I thought in 2008 that Microsoft would turn around eventually and implement XHR + CORS
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:44): eventually implementing something and eventually removing something are different beasts, though, as you know better than I :P
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:45): Or "we don't know if there's actual legacy compat, but the tiny possibility of problems outweighs the tinier gains of removing support"
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (00:47): gains of removing support?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:47): in the end Microsoft will want to comply with the standards of the platform
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:47): and if the standards say that "utf-32" does not mean shit, they will play
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (00:47): you are a very optimistic fellow.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:47): interop, closer to consistency of encoding detection between browsers (as long as you don't hit the heuristic/locale steps), helping utf-32 die
88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762 (00:48): Is *anyone* trying to implement the encoding detection spec?  Does anyone know if it's actually implementable?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:48): 7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6: it's what has happened in the decade I've been involved time and again, but sure, nothing is certain
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:48): 88d4d34a8064a4ff39fd5e144eea7762: Opera implemented it, I believe

7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (00:49): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, i'm looking forward to vorbis support then. in 2017, when i don't need it anymore, because the mp3 patents ‚Ä¶ hmm. probably are still going to be out there somewhere, lurking.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:50): time for mickey mp3 laws
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:50): in the end Microsoft ships a browser like anyone else, and browsers are driven a lot by what developers want, and they want browsers to work the same way

7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (00:50): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, if large inconsistencies like CSS weirdness and media formats happen to work for them, i do not believe small inconsistencies have any chance unless they actually drive it.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:51): they might not move as fast as the others, but they have <canvas> now, they have full CSS 2.1 support, etc.
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:51): well, at least there's some evidence that they're willing to make breaking changes to their own legacy compat (eg. read-only event objects)
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (00:51): funny, developers i know constantly tell me browsers are driven by what browser companies want. that is some nice loop ;D
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:51): all the things we thought were not going to happen back when we started with the WHATWG in 2004
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (00:51): IE has <canvas>? wow. long time no see.
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:51): so maybe I'm pretty optimistic, but there's some history to support it

06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:52): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e: supporting new features and breaking existing ones are different classes, though; i don't think adding support for Canvas is evidence for making breaking changes (though as I said, there's at least some evidence for that)
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (00:52): edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e, you may be right after all, because killing off UTF-32 slowly is almost as good as killing it off fast.
ab31f84eb13407c876da2bd14a02402e (00:53): it's been 7 years of WHATWG?  That deserves a "wow" of its own. :)
7f9405da4034bf43083e64b57302a8e6 (00:53): so it might not matter if they care much, if they do at all.

edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (00:53): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: a lot of things were breaking changes, for pretty much every browser we've had those
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (00:54): modulo quirks mode, though (though I pretty much ignore the details of that, being fortunate enough to not have horrible legacy stuff to maintain)
